G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper under G.L. c. 212, § 4 and G.L. c. 223, § 2 because this action seeks damages for personal injury arising within Middlesex County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper under G.L. c. 212, § 4 and G.L. c. 223, § 2 because this action seeks damages for personal injury arising within Middlesex County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in the **Lowell District Court** pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the cause of action arose in this District.

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 449 N.E.2d 331 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, storeowners owe a duty to maintain their premises in a reasonably safe condition for invited customers and to protect them from foreseeable risks of harm.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: The excerpt is a dissent focused almost entirely on proximate cause and foreseeability of a criminal attack on a college campus, not on the general duty of storeowners (or possessors of land) to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition for invitees. While the case as a whole concerns premises liability and duties of a college to its students, the quoted portion neither states nor develops the specific Massachusetts rule about storeowners’ duty to invited customers. Thus, as used here, this citation does not clearly support the claimed proposition.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff had the burden of proving “that the defendant[s] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.” Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969).

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 297 N..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, storeowners owe a duty to maintain their premises in a reasonably safe condition for invited customers and to protect them from foreseeable risks of harm.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 297 N..support_reasoning: The excerpt is from a concurrence focused on abolishing the licensee/invitee distinction and critiquing continued special treatment of trespassers, so it does not itself articulate the storeowner’s duty. However, Mounsey v. Ellard as a whole is a leading Massachusetts case expanding occupiers’ duties and rejecting rigid status categories, thereby supporting the broader proposition that owners owe lawful entrants (including customers) a duty of reasonable care to protect them from foreseeable harm. The support comes from the case’s overall holding, not this specific quoted passage.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 297 N..relevant_excerpt: [Full articulation of the duty appears in the main opinion rather than this concurrence; in substance, the court holds that an occupier owes to lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care under all the circumstances, rejecting the former invitee/licensee distinction. The provided concurring excerpt does not contain that language directly.]

Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea C.raw_text: Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co., 343 Mass. 263, 178 N.E.2d 286 (1961)
Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea C.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff, as a business invitee, a duty to exercise reasonable care to ensure merchandise and shelving were secure and safe.
Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea C.case_name: Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.
Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea C.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states the duty owed by the store to its customers: to keep the premises reasonably safe, while clarifying that the store is not an insurer and liability depends on negligence. Although the court ultimately finds no negligence on the facts, it affirms the underlying duty of reasonable care regarding dangerous conditions created by merchandise (here, spilled pine oil from a bottle on display). This aligns with the proposition that the defendant owed a business invitee a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep merchandise-related conditions safe.
Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea C.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant owed to customers a duty to keep the premises reasonably safe for their use. He, however, is not an insurer of safety. Where, without action for which he is responsible, a dangerous condition arises, the law allows him reasonable opportunity to become informed of the danger and to take measures to remedy it. He is not liable, in such a case, unless he is negligent in failing to inform himself and to take appropriate action.”

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..raw_text: Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368, 930 N.E.2d 142 (2010)
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Defendant knew or should have known that the stacking of boxes posed a foreseeable risk of falling objects injuring customers.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion deals exclusively with premises liability for slip-and-fall injuries on snow and ice, and the abolition of the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction. It does not involve or analyze any facts about stacked boxes, falling objects, or merchandising displays, nor does it discuss a defendant’s knowledge of risks from stacked items. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that the defendant knew or should have known that box stacking posed a foreseeable risk of falling objects injuring customers.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’ … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 849 N.E.2d.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain its premises in a safe condition was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 849 N.E.2d.support_reasoning: The case addresses duty and, to some extent, causation, but the court explicitly declines to find that the defendant’s conduct was the direct and proximate cause of the officer’s injuries. Instead, it holds only that Kask owed a duty of reasonable care regarding storage of firearms and that a jury must decide breach and causal relation. Thus, the opinion does not establish that failure to maintain the premises (or secure the gun cabinet) was the direct and proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries; it merely allows a negligence claim to proceed on that theory.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 849 N.E.2d.relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. … We therefore reverse summary judgment on the negligence claim and leave to a jury the determination whether Kask exercised reasonable care.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Plaintiff exercised due care for her own safety and did not contribute to the occurrence.

Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 43.raw_text: Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 437 N.E.2d 171 (1982)
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 43.proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff sustained the following damages: medical expenses, lost wages, physical pain, emotional distress, and loss of normal life activities.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 43.support_reasoning: The case is a DES class action addressing whether Massachusetts recognizes certain causes of action for negligent infliction of emotional distress without physical harm, prenatal injury, wrongful life-type claims, and market-share liability. It does not set out or discuss a list of compensable damages such as medical expenses, lost wages, pain, emotional distress, and loss of normal life activities as a general rule of negligence damages. The opinion is about the availability of particular causes of action and prerequisites (e.g., physical harm requirement), not about the categories of damages recoverable once negligence and causation are established, so it does not support the specific damages proposition cited.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85A.proposition: Defendant’s conduct amounts to a breach of the duty of reasonable care under G.L. c. 231, § 85A, and relevant Massachusetts negligence principles.

Glidden v. Maglio, Inc., 430 Mass. 694,.raw_text: Glidden v. Maglio, Inc., 430 Mass. 694, 723 N.E.2d 655 (2000)
Glidden v. Maglio, Inc., 430 Mass. 694,.proposition: Defendant’s conduct amounts to a breach of the duty of reasonable care under G.L. c. 231, § 85A, and relevant Massachusetts negligence principles.
Glidden v. Maglio, Inc., 430 Mass. 694,.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss negligence and the duty of reasonable care, but it ultimately holds that the plaintiffs failed to prove causation and affirms summary judgment for the defendant. The court expressly declines to decide whether the defendant even owed a duty of care under Massachusetts negligence principles and does not interpret or apply G.L. c. 231, § 85A. Thus, the case does not stand as authority that the defendant’s conduct amounted to a breach of the duty of reasonable care under that statute or general negligence law.
Glidden v. Maglio, Inc., 430 Mass. 694,.relevant_excerpt: “With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss…. Because the plaintiffs have failed to meet their burden on the issue of causation, we need not decide whether they presented sufficient evidence to show that the defendant owed a duty of care to them sufficient to survive the defendant’s motion for summary judgment.”

Banaghan v. Dewey, 340 Mass. 73, 162 N.E.proposition: Defendant’s conduct amounts to a breach of the duty of reasonable care under G.L. c. 231, § 85A, and relevant Massachusetts negligence principles.
Banaghan v. Dewey, 340 Mass. 73, 162 N.E.support_reasoning: The opinion does analyze negligence and breach of reasonable care duties, but it does not involve or construe G.L. c. 231, § 85A at all. The only statutory negligence provision cited is G.L. c. 231, § 85, regarding the burden of proving contributory negligence. Because § 85A (dealing with motor vehicle owner liability) is not mentioned or applied, the case cannot be cited as authority that the defendant’s conduct constituted a breach of reasonable care under that specific statute, though it does support general Massachusetts negligence principles for landlords and elevator maintenance contractors.
Banaghan v. Dewey, 340 Mass. 73, 162 N.E.relevant_excerpt: In the Peterson case the defendant urges that the plaintiff elevator operator was contributorily negligent. The burden of showing this was upon the defendant, G. L. c. 231, § 85, and despite evidence from which it could be inferred that he was aware of the defective condition of the elevator, we cannot rule as a matter of law that he was negligent in continuing to operate it. ... Here the jury could have found that the elevator company had contracted with the trustees, at least to inspect the elevator, and at most to maintain it in "A-1 safe condition." ... there was ample evidence ... of its negligence in inspecting and maintaining the elevator.

Bohan v. Ritacco, 449 Mass. 101, 865 N.E.proposition: Defendant’s conduct amounts to a breach of the duty of reasonable care under G.L. c. 231, § 85A, and relevant Massachusetts negligence principles.
Bohan v. Ritacco, 449 Mass. 101, 865 N.E.support_reasoning: The opinion is a juvenile care-and-protection/evidence decision, not a negligence or motor vehicle liability case. It does not interpret G.L. c. 231, § 85A, nor does it analyze or apply Massachusetts negligence principles regarding a defendant’s duty of reasonable care. The court addresses evidentiary admissibility of children’s out-of-court statements and standards for temporary custody/removal, not breach of a duty of care by a tort defendant, so it cannot support the cited negligence proposition.
Bohan v. Ritacco, 449 Mass. 101, 865 N.E.relevant_excerpt: "Removal after a temporary custody hearing is appropriate if the judge finds there is a ‘fair preponderance of the evidence’ that a child is ‘suffering from serious abuse or neglect or is in immediate danger of serious abuse or neglect and that immediate removal of the child is necessary to protect the child from serious abuse or neglect.’ G. L. c. 119, § 24. Care & Protection of Robert, supra at 68."

Poirier v. Plymouth, 374 Mass. 206, 372.proposition: Defendant’s conduct amounts to a breach of the duty of reasonable care under G.L. c. 231, § 85A, and relevant Massachusetts negligence principles.
Poirier v. Plymouth, 374 Mass. 206, 372.support_reasoning: The excerpted opinion is a concurrence focused on the ‘hidden defect’ rule and the sufficiency of the evidence under that theory; it does not discuss G.L. c. 231, § 85A or articulate a general standard for breach of the duty of reasonable care in Massachusetts negligence law. The concurrence explicitly treats the case as governed by premises liability principles related to hidden defects, and it does not analyze or establish that the defendant’s conduct constituted a breach of reasonable care under § 85A. Thus, this text does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Poirier v. Plymouth, 374 Mass. 206, 372.relevant_excerpt: “This action was tried by the parties and submitted to the jury on the plaintiff’s claim that he was injured by reason of a hidden or concealed defect on the defendant’s premises, of which defect the defendant was aware or should have been aware through the exercise of reasonable care. The jury returned a substantial verdict for the plaintiff. The defendant appealed, contending that there was insufficient evidence to support the verdict… this court is ordering that the verdict and judgment for the plaintiff be reinstated, holding that the evidence was sufficient to support the verdict.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B and 6C.proposition: b. Pre- and post-judgment interest pursuant to **G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B and 6C**;
